title: Tuesday, 22nd October 2019

Given the speculation around a Prosus bid had been considerable and the fact that it hadn't explicitly happened was one of the reasons why the Just Eat-Takeaway combo was trading so badly.

PBateman Cat Rock ordering a greasy takeaway as we speak
BE11:11am

See, for example, Liberum's Ian Whittaker back in early September, as quoted here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2019-09-03/

marktime 1MDB casting a long shadow
BE11:12am

We think it is increasingly likely the Just Eat bid will not be agreed, just as the agreed private equity bid for Scout24, was similarly rejected by shareholders. We would also agree the bid undervalues the company and it is likely that other bidders will emerge with the soon to be listed Prosus the most likely candidate in our view.

dingotooth Morning - transitioning from Lurk to searing visible light.
11:12 am
BE11:12am

ncreasingly, this looks a re-run of what happened with the mainly German-based property and automotive classified portal Scout24 (BUY, €58 TP). In that situation, management agreed a bid for €46 per share from private equity, which was then rejected by shareholders who said the price was too low (the bid valued Scout24 at 14-15x adjusted EBITDA vs. the c. 19x paid for ZPG in the UK, which was an arguably inferior asset). Shareholders look to be justified so far - the Scout24 share price at the close of yesterday was €52.8, a significant premium to the bid;
We agree the bid price looks too low. It implies 770-780p per share vs. our 1360p DCF-based target price. Just Eat's online classified portal model is similar to AutoTrader and Rightmove's, just at a much earlier stage of development. As the clear market leader in most of the markets in which it operates, it should therefore expect to see a hockey stick effect on margins and profits in the medium to longer-term, as its gains a disproportionate share of the benefits.
The stake in iFood is critical. As Eminence points out, iFood is the clear leader in the Brazilian market, which is a huge opportunity (according to its statement, iFood is 17x larger than its nearest competitor). We value Just Eat's stake at £600m, but that is likely to be very conservative;
We see other bidders emerging. We see less chance of an Amazon and Uber Eats coming through (we think the recent announced by the CMA in the UK of an investigation into the online players will discourage the global giants from acquiring Just Eat) but we think Prosus, the soon to be listed spin-off from Naspers, is the most likely candidate for a bid, especially given it is the other major investor in iFood. Acquiring Just Eat would give Prosus immediate market leadership in 12 of the 13 countries plus the technology of SkipTheDishes, which has had phenomenal success in Canada.

gadfly Any research on Lloyds and Reckitt?
BE11:12am

Similar speculation since from UBS and Morgan Stanley, among others, if memory serves.

BE11:13am

In terms of today comment, here's Jefferies saying "yes, this makes sense"

11:13 am
BE11:13am

This changes the narrative at Prosus. Versus a simple 'discounted way into Tencent' with the prospect of buybacks improved (in some investors' minds) by the tax situation of Prosus (vs Naspers) this shows that PRX is instead ambitious to grow food, payments and classifieds. Using most of its net cash to acquire JE eliminates the buyback option, and acquired cashflow will presumably be ploughed back into growth investment (losses). Takeaway.com will likely counter. Questions over the DHER stake will arise. Will a strengthened but private, poorly disclosed food business be valued higher within PRX than it was by the market? Stakes are raised for the December 3rd CMD (if the situation is resolved by then).

BE11:23am

RB has reported Q3 organic sales growth of 1.6% (of which 3% is price/mix); consensus was expecting 3%. Helped by a currency benefit, reported sales increased by 5% to £3.29bn. This takes YTD organic sales growth to 0.9%.
■ Health registered organic growth of -0.3% driven by a c£70m re-stocking benefit at infant formula in China (IFCN +7%; sales in China were negative ex the re-stocking), but offset by a 7% decline in OTC and a 2.5% decline in Other Health (Durex, VMS, Dettol). Organic growth at Hygiene Home was 4.5% (but flattered by litigation resolution; the underlying performance was around 3%).
■ Management have reduced FY19 targets; organic sales growth of 0-2%, previously 2-3% (consensus 2%) and a modest decline in operating margins, previously no change (consensus 26.6% -10bps).

luzh @marktime do you think the difference between a homemade sandwich and a pret sandwich hits the bottom line on renting a flat in London?

marktime Er yes and it is a symptom of everything else
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Expect cons EPS cuts of 3-5% and a material negative stock reaction. Another Disappointment ... Q3 LFL 1.6% vs cons 3.2% (and MSe 2.6%). RB's weak Q319 makes it 13/14 disappointments in a row. Whilst we expected a weak quarter the challenges in the Health business are significantly worse than we expected at -0.3% LFL vs cons +3.7% (on an underlying basis Health was down -4% LFL).

BE11:24am

This time the major weakness came from retailer purchasing / inventory issues with flu related products (e.g. Mucinex, Airborne). Hygiene Home performed well at 4.5% vs cons 2.5%, although on an underlying basis LFL growth was ~3%. If we ex-out the positive boost to LFL for both Health (lapping last year's outage) and to Hygiene Home (one off settlement) we estimate group underlying LFL was down ~-1%.

BE11:25am

Another Guide Down ... Missing our already adjusted down estimate of 2.6% for Q3 is disappointing, albeit following the recent trend now missing 13/14 quarters in a row. The problems came from further execution issues within the Health business, which continues to struggle. Management cut guidance for the second time this year with topline guidance cut to 0-2% LFL (vs 2-3% previously), and a margin guidance cut to "modest decline" (vs flat previously).

tangledodyssey Surfeit of content through a chase for ever more choice might just destroy the economics, though, through a race to the bottom on subscription rates?

11:25 am
BE11:25am

We have cut our FY19 forecasts to 0.7% LFL (vs 1.6%) and -50bps margins (vs flat). It is worth noting margins fell 100bps in 2017 and 60bps in 2018, so this will be the third year in a row of negative margins (with 2020 also likely to see a reset in our view).

tangledodyssey FATDAZ: Yes, Chick-a-Fil is politically verboten, it seems.

A reminder that the cornerstone of Reckitt's business is to sell stuff that's generic and probably doesn't really work at a premium price, because the public tend to believe premium priced stuff that doesn't work is more likely to work than cheap stuff that doesn't work.

To be constructive here, investors need to assume a combination of: 1) the multiple challenges that the business faces are down to execution and underinvestment, 2) the new outsider CEO can present a clear vision and plan to turn the business around that investors will buy into, 3) that 2020 is largely de-risked with consensus already assuming a material margin reset in February 2020 (we assume a 150bps reset), 4) the problems that have beset the business particularly in Health can be resolved with reinvestment and/or new strategy ...

BE11:37am

Tui has reacted well to the collapse of rival operator Thomas Cook and waning risks around Brexit. However, the company’s fiscal 2020 guidance expected with year-end results in December will likely be wide and below consensus forecasts due to demand uncertainty and costs tied to Boeing’s grounded 737 Max jet, Morgan Stanley said. Weak free cashflow next year has also meant a growing risk to Tui’s dividend, the broker added.Based on the 737 Max returning to service in April rather than December, Tui’s costs to cover flight disruption next year would rise from €50m to €150m and pre-tax earnings would take a 10 per cent hit, Morgan Stanley said. A worst case scenario where the Max was grounded for the whole of 2020 would cost Tui €350m it said.

Tui enjoyed a record day’s trading when Thomas Cook collapsed and its customers rebooked their cancelled holidays, which should underpin first-quarter 2020 figures, said Morgan Stanley. However, it also highlighted that Tui chose to increase 2020 capacity by around 10 per cent by adding 1.5m extra holidays. Whether they sell will depend on consumer confidence and competitors’ responses, the broker said. With Tui increasing marketing spend and improving technology systems, the benefit of increased capacity may not be immediately obvious, said the broker. It saw Tui guiding towards a 2020 pre-tax earnings range of €800m to €1bn, which would be between 10 and 30 per cent below the consensus forecast.

On the Beach is strategically increasing its marketing investment
to make sure it gains the market share available as a result of the
failure of Thomas Cook. All the brands: onthebeach.co.uk;
sunshine.co.uk; Classic Collection; and Classic Package have
unprecedented opportunities to grow their customer bases.

marktime Hydrazine?
11:41 am
BE11:41am

In-line trading statement. On the Beach announces today that trading is in
line with management’s expectations. These expectations were revised
downwards only on 9 August but, given the general economic uncertainty, it
is reassuring that the balance of the year panned out as management expected.
 Increasing marketing investment. As noted above, On the Beach is
increasing the marketing investment behind its brands. It is currently a quiet
period for holiday bookings but it is probably important to make sure that the
target customer base is reminded about On the Beach ahead of the key
booking season. Along with online marketing, there have been some highlyvisible
outdoor and newspaper campaigns to help to raise awareness.
 Cost of flights will come back down to earth. The failure of Thomas Cook
has triggered a spike in short-haul flight prices. Presumably this is, in part, the
result of travellers with plans in place being obliged to buy replacement flights
at short notice. We expect demand, and supply, to begin to normalise by the
time bookings begin in earnest after Christmas but this remains uncertain.
 Not changing FY20E forecasts. Market share gains could add materially to
our forecasts (for details, see our note ((What’s the Story) Morning Glory 17
June 2019). But, given the early stage in the year and the uncertainties
surrounding the sector, it would be premature to start changing forecasts.

BE11:50am

The statement notes that market conditions in the UK remain challenging with business confidence remaining weak and leisure confidence in decline, coinciding with political and economic uncertainty. This has continued into Q3, impacting the Regions in particular (c.80% rooms). The group re-iterated its cost headwind guidance from earlier in the year. It continues to expect a net margin headwind of £45m (£20-25m net cost headwind; £10m Costa dis-synergies; £12m German losses).

11:50 am
BE11:51am

Overall, the continued soft UK RevPAR performance is not surprising, however the decline in leisure confidence will put even more pressure on RevPAR performance. We currently forecast a 5% decline in FY20 Regional LFL RevPAR and -2% in London for the full year, however continued macro uncertainty could put more pressure on these assumptions. WTB note that every 1% movement in RevPAR impacts PBT by £12-15m. At first glance we do not expect to change our recently downgraded PBT forecast of £361m. However, we are c.4% below consensus, and we believe consensus should move down towards our numbers.

A. M. @YourGrannyOnBongos -- I would think that uncertainty etc. would cause people to cut down on such things (to some extent).
BE11:51am

Overall, UK LFL RevPAR was -5.2% yoy in H2 versus the overall market which was down -2.4%. Within this occupancy was -180bps and rate was -3% to £64.07. London saw accommodation sales growth of 4.5% in H1 with a strong Q2.
Regional UK RevPAR declined 5.9%. The group noted that the UK regional market has been difficult particularly in the business segment. During the period 666 new rooms were opened in the UK (GBYf: 1,050) and the group is now operating c.77K UK rooms. In Germany, it will open c. 2K rooms this year and it reiterated that it will lose £12m this year.

maintenance capex, £150-200m investment in new UK capacity and £300-350m investment in Germany.

Morgan Stanley off the call:

BE11:54am

he meeting was solid though, with no particularly great surprises:Positives: (1) Company would expect a nice recovery in corporate hotel demand if the Brexit deal is passed, but said it could take time to come. Leisure demand has been holding up well. (2). Focusing more on optimising current UK estate via Premier Plus rooms (£10-20 or 15-30% rate uplift on ~2% of rooms should add a small tailwind in FY21), and more churn, which suggests slower expansion, but lower capex so better FCF. (3) Latest new German hotel in Hamburg has matured faster than any comparable UK hotel. “Increasingly confident of replicating the UK’s success”. Pipeline up to an impressive 8k rooms. (4) Leading KPIs on quality vs value score, and purchase intention, a reminder of its strong customer proposition. (5) Direct distribution up to 98% of bookings, which saves on commission and keeps PI close to its customers. (6) Strong balance sheet with close to zero net debt (pre IFRS 16), and ~£0.5bn of headroom to 3x lease adjusted FFO. Negatives: (1) Company cautious on the demand outlook and also on high supply growth in the regions running at 2-3%. Noted its Q3 is tracking similar to Q2, yet the market data is ~150bps better, suggesting ongoing underperformance. (2) Slowing UK expansion and a 18% drop in H1 maintenance capex (partly timing) seems at odds with earlier comments that investment would not be curtailed in the event of a downturn; company noted more capex in optimisation (extensions, Premier Plus). (3) No additional cost savings, given these have already risen from £150m to £310m. (4) RevPAR underperformance vs Travelodge put down to PI’s higher skew to regions and corporates, Super rooms (which Premier Plus is emulating), and lower base. (5) Conversion of RevPAR (company guides to £12-15m EBIT sensitivity to 1% on RevPAR) looks high on £1.3bn of accommodation sales but is partly explained by ~£0.3bn of F&B revenue that comes from hotel guests (6) Germany will still make a small loss in FY21 (vs £(12)m loss in FY20) as acquired hotels being refurbished, hopes for a material unit contribution in FY22 and will communicate more next year (NB much of this will go into the high overheads).

We expect consensus forecasts to come down to around our level (£384m) following the release (£384m vs £404m currently ie c5% lower). RevPAR -4.2% in line with our expectations. H1 PBT ahead largely due to more even cost phasing than we had assumed. F&B also better. Outlook is cautious with room openings trimmed to c3000 vs 3000-3500 previously. Overall we think expectations were by now fairly low going into this release and so we do not expect a significant underperformance on the back of the results. We expect the share performance from here will be more driven by Brexit newsflow in the short term.

Pendragon has, bottom line, performed better than we expected in Q3, but there are big distortions here between LFL and total sales and gross profit across all segments. Cost reduction has driven the improvement in PBT. It remains far too early to call the recovery from a trading and strategic perspective. We revise our bottom of the range FY19E LBT from £32.8m to £18.6m. While sentiment in a soft Brexit scenario may favour Pendragon, our preferred play would be Vertu, given the track record and balance sheet strength. Raise SoTP TP from 7p to 9p. Maintain Sell.
